Issues.Title: Use correct plural form for ivy
Issues.Body:
**You should review each commit independently, it'll be easier.**

---------
Plural ICU expressions depend on the locale (different languages have different plural forms). Until now the locale was hard coded as `en-US`.
This PR refactors all of the localization code that was previously living in `@angular/common`. Everything but the locale data has been moved to `@angular/core`, making it possible to get the correct plural form. Since we plan on refactoring all of this later and we didn't want to create a breaking change for that now, everything is still publicly exported by `@angular/common`, but the code is actually in `@angular/core`, making it possible to use it in core (core cannot import from common).
For compatibility reasons, if you use ivy with AOT and bootstrap your app with `bootstrapModule` then the `LOCALE_ID` token will be set automatically for ivy, which is then used to get the correct plural form.

‚ö†Ô∏è For JIT you need to call `…µsetLocaleId` manually to define the `LOCALE_ID` before bootstrap. Same thing if you don't use the compat mode and start your app with `renderComponent`. We expect this to change once we start adding the new i18n APIs, so don't rely on this function (there's a reason why it's a private export).

### BREAKING CHANGE:

In v5, we deprecated support for the intl API in order to improve the browser support. We are now removing these deprecated APIs for v8. See the original change here for more info on why: #18284.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngcc - handle prototype pseudo-member from typings file in ESM5 host
Issues.Body:
When using the `Esm5ReflectionHost` to process a JavaScript program, it may
come across a symbol that has been imported from a TypeScript typings file.
In this case the compiler may pass the host the `prototype` symbol as an
export of the class.

But this pseudo-member symbol has no declarations, which caused the code
in `reflectMembers()` to crash. Now in this case we just quietly ignore
this symbol.

tsc `getCurrentDirectory` directory doesn't return a posix separated normalized path. While `rootDir` and `rootDirs` should return posix separated paths, it's best to not assume as other paths within the compiler options can be returned not posix separated such as `basePath`

See: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/blob/master/src/compiler/sys.ts#L635

This partially fixes #29140, however there needs to be a change in the CLI as well to handle this, as at the moment we are leaking devkit paths which is not correct.

Fixes #29140

Issues.Title: fix(@ngtools/webpack): `getCurrentDirectory` should not return a devkit path
Issues.Body:
At the moment we are leaking devkit paths as `getCurrentDirectory` is used by the ngtsc compiler if no `rootDir` directories is provided.

`getCurrentDirectory` is also used to construct the `rootDirs` option which is causing this to be incorrect as under Windows as `rootDirs` will be have an invalid value example: `/c/foo/bar`

This PR complements https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/29151

**Note** that this currently works because we are normalizing paths with posix seperators and is mimicking the behaviour of the logical file system used by the ngtsc.

Fixes: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/13849

Issues.Body:
Rolling this forward with a README explaining our agreed-on policy.

@cyrilletuzi we want to find a fair way to include extensions from the community, including yours. We are stuck on how to do this without confusing users with a set of overlapping extensions - we assume that many users will install all of our recommendations. That forces us to pick winners and that's not a good position for us to be in.
The governance constraint is the primary one we'll use for guidance in version 8. So the easiest path to get your code in front of users is to make it first-party.
Happy to discuss further.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

Currently, the only output of MatRadioGroup is (change).

Issues.Title: improve support for readonly controls OR improve how to subscribe to form changes with disabled controls
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
Suggest there be a clean way to either a) get data from disabled controls or alternately b) improve support for readonly controls. Solution is requested in terms of best practices and/or feature enhancements.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
When using a custom component with a form, the form changes need to be watched and emitted to the parent. If the form has values that ought to be readonly, til now I've used the disabled flag *as a workaround* because a) readonly fields have poor visual appearance -- they are not greyed out b) formbuilder supports initializing as disabled, but not initializing as readonly (as shown here https://angular.io/api/forms/FormBuilder#control).

However, when using the workaround, it becomes difficult to watch and emit changes "cleanly" for disabled fields e.g. subscribing to form.valueChanges doesn't get disabled fields, necessitating a duplicative call to getRawValue() after subscribing to changes, to get all the form field data.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Potential solutions:
a) advise if using readonly attribute is the best practice, rather than using 'disabled' to prevent data entry. If so, hoping there can be some improvements on styling of readonly controls (e.g. they should be greyed out), and also formbuilder should be able to initialize them as readonly. 

b) if angular doesn't intend to support readonly atribute, and instead rely on 'disabled' attribute, then ideally there would be something similar to form.valueChanges that actually gets all form values including disabled controls. 

If (b) is the solution path, then it's low priority admittedly, since it just avoids a little code duplication. I think the core question though is whether there ought to be better support for readonly controls, and if the angular framework intends to maintain a distinction between 'disabled' vs. 'readonly'. 

For my purposes, I mainly disable controls in order to achieve the readonly effect, and then I make a point to getRawValue data so i get all the data. From my research on stackoverflow etc. it appears others do similar workarounds.
